course.description: Prime numbers, unique factorization, modular arithmetic, quadratic number fields, finite fields, p-adic numbers, coding theory, computational complexity.

reviews.author: mathling
reviews.comment_content: Basic number theory. Main concepts: Fermat Little Theorem , Euclidean algorithm , modular arithmetic , Will's theorem , convolution , Gaussian integers are primes. It maybe a bit abstract if you are not mature in Math enough and you will easily get lost in the lectures, but the problems are quite computational(in the exams). The pre-requisite is not needed essentially.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is abstract in lecture, esp. this is a new area for most of the students. However, you can visit his office when you are confused where he will make things clear and you will get it after consulting him.
reviews.comment_grading: I forgot the distribution , can check on web anyway. One point is that the final covers mostly materials before midterm(maybe due to to the algebraic number theory part(Gaussian integers and primes) is sort of outside syllabus and was not tested as he emphasize this class is elementary number theory.)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite high as there are 5 hws in my memory. Most of them are non trivial(Can't be easily googled and takes time to digest)

reviews.author: PeterLin
reviews.title: Number Theory and Applications
reviews.comment_content:
Textbook for the course:
Number Theory by Róbert Freud and Edit Gyarmati
https://bookstore.ams.org/amstext-48/
Chapter 1. Basic Notions
Chapter 2. Congruences
Chapter 3. Congruences of Higher Degree
------Midterm------
Chapter 4. Legendre and Jacobi Symbols
Chapter 5. Prime Numbers
Chapter 6. Arithmetic Functions
Chapter 7. Diophantine Equations
Chapter 9. Algebraic and Transcendental Numbers
chap. 1~3 are covered in midterm,  chap. 1~7 are covered in final (chapter 9 is taught but not tested)

The book is well-written and those knowledges covered are fundamental in number theory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xiong prepares hand-written lecture notes (simplified version of textbook) and goes through them during lectures, this boosts his teaching speed a lot compared to previous years. To me, However, the teaching is kind of "dry" and I prefer to read them by myself or read the book directly.

He also offers a "moral lesson" (same as 1023? lol) to give his though on how to deal with anxiety and stress in college life, but I think most people taking this course should be year 3 or 4... :P
reviews.comment_grading:
hw 5%
quiz 5%
midterm 35%
final 55%
You may see the instruction in the attached file.

Midterm (100 in total, 25*4 questions, lecture time open book)
Mean: 71.29 High: 100 Low: 10

Final (100 in total, 10*10 questions, 3 hours open book)
Mean: 59.15 High: 100         Low: 17

We can use online calculator in both midterm and final, and the professor makes numbers large in calculation questions to prevent guessing. The proving questions in mt/final is more or less similar to questions in the textbook.
Because hint for every question is offered in the textbook, the mean for hw is very high. The mean for each quiz is around 6~7.5. I got full in midterm and 87 in final, resulting in A.

So I think the grade is ok and you maybe need to score very high in exams to get A+, so not easy.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload depends.

Our group was assigned 2 homeworks in the whole semester (10 selected problems from textbook each), so the homework is light.
Quiz is a bit annoying but the question is standard with some small tricks, and each quiz only takes 1% of the whole grade, so not a big deal.
But from the grading scheme, the mt and final is important and the professor suggests that we do as much exercise as possible. The textbook has tons of questions and a short hint is available for each question(only very few questions have full solutions, I guess it's because this is a new book). Sometimes hint is helpful while other times you can get nothing from it, so I just finish a portion of those questions. I think the difficulty of exams is not as much as the difficulty of the hard questions in the book.

reviews.comment_workload:
Not too heavy, but you definitely need to spend some time

Most of the time you will need to go through the notes and recording again after the lecture, also an assignment every week (with some exception, 9 assignments in total), 5-8 questions for each assignment, it may take up to a whole day to finish it. They are useful in helping you understand the content so I recommend treating them more seriously.

For the exams, you need to prepare and be familiar with the concept, might need to take a day or two to focus on revising the notes before the exam in addition to the reviews after each lecture

reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, it is not easy to understand the material in class. The Professor used to prepare a presentation-liked teaching with some example which would not be found in the textbook. It is better to read the notes before attending the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is relatively good. I got a total mark (~80%) below the mean but still got a "B".
reviews.comment_workload: There is an assignment every week. I think they are a bit hard but good for revision. You can follow the flow of the teaching if you make good use of the homework. There is only a final exam at the end of the semester, which has fair difficulty.

reviews.author: secret_person
reviews.comment_content:
The content is standard for an elementary number course. If you are a pure math student, then it is advised you should take this course regardless of your specialty.

p-adic numbers, quadratic field are not mentioned this year. Prof. Xiong presented the content in a way such that a minimal algebraic background would suffice.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xiong is very detailed and meticulous in teaching. He is explained every details very clearly with moderate pace, this could potential benefit novice. However, occasionally he just focus on trivial details, making the true meaning of theorem/formula obscure.

The tutorial TA given is also very informative, he focus largely on numerical and concrete examples, which is nice if you're new to number theory.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW: 20%, Midterm: 32%, Final: 48%. The overall score has mean around 78, with SD 20. From an objective perspective, it is not difficult to get B or above.

When grading homework, the TA selectively grades easiest questions. I recall in an instance, we had ten questions, two of them extremely challenging. I spent a lot of time to eventually figure it out. However, the TA turns out just ignore those two questions, and only mark the easiest three problems (you can finish these 3 questions with just 6 lines). The same happens for every other assignments. Although I cannot assert whether the choice of question is intentional or a coincidence, the marking behavior severely curtail advantages of above-average students.

Finally, the ultimate debacle is the grade Prof. Xiong gives out. He ridiculously graded by curve on a class size of just 40, and the apocalyptic consequence is that there is not a single A+. With numerous people obtaining overall marks around 98-99, the highest grade is merely only A. His transcendental way of grading amuses good and bad students alike.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is moderate, largely consists of weekly or bi-weekly assignments. Each assignment consists of around ten questions, both easy and challenging. The TA will only grade certain problems (of course you don't know which will he mark before hand).

For midterm and final exams, the content is very straightforward and standard, time is sufficient, no trick question involved. However, you should always do as much exercises as possible.

reviews.author: Trevis@MATH
reviews.comment_content:
This  course covers basic topics in elementary number theory: Fundamental theorem of arithmetic, greatest common divisor, unique factorization, primes and distributions, congruence, basic arithmetic functions, primitive roots, quadratic reciprocity, diophantine approximation. Some other topics.

Textbook: I. Niven, H.S. Zuckerman, H.L. Montgomery, An introduction to the theory of numbers, 5th edition, John Wiley & Sons, Inc, 1991. See
http://www.fuchs-braun.com/media/532896481f9c1c47ffff8077fffffff0.pdf
reviews.comment_teaching: In fact, the professor and the TA are nice and helpful. They are likely to explain the topics quite understandingly.
